title: Remove "simply" from Readme in base
body:
Second instance of "simply":

Our usage of "simply" in the Readme was called out on Twitter today https://twitter.com/iamsapegin/status/856880857570832384?s=09. Best to avoid its use since what is "simple" is relative.

txtx @jongold

title: Remove "simply" from Readme
body: Our usage of "simply" in the Readme was called out on Twitter today https://twitter.com/iamsapegin/status/856880857570832384?s=09. Best to avoid its use since what is "simple" is relative.

title: import/no-duplicates vs import/no-named-default
Add rollup.config.*.js to import/no-extraneous-dependencies ignore list
body: As other tools, it's fairly common to have multiple Rollup configuration files. This pattern seems to be used by Rollup in [their own configuration](https://github.com/rollup/rollup/blob/master/rollup.config.cli.js).

title: Multi-line if statements - breaks and indentation
Mocha arrow-function and unnamed function errors.
body:
Hello community I am receiving errors whenever I am using using `describe(function(){})` in my code.
How can I get rid of these errors?
Here is my .eslintrc.yml.

```
extends: airbnb-base
plugins:
  - standard
  - promise
env:
    node: true
    mocha: true
rules:
    indent: ["error", 2]
    semi: ["error", "always", {omitLastInOneLineBlock: true}]
    no-eval: ["error"]
    no-trailing-spaces: ["error"]
    one-var-declaration-per-line: ["error", "initializations"]
    no-irregular-whitespace: ["error"]
    no-var: ["error"]
    no-empty: ["error"]
    linebreak-style: ["error", "unix"]
    eol-last: ["error", "always"]
    no-console: ["warn", {"allow": ["warn", "error", "info"]}]
    no-use-before-define: ["error", { "functions": false }]
    no-unused-vars: ["error", {"argsIgnorePattern":"^next"}]
```
Tried to add mocha-plugin like so:
```
plugins:
- mocha
rules:
mocha/no-arrow-function: "error"
```
but it still gives me errors.

title: Turn `ignorePureComponent` option on for react/prefer-stateless-function
body:
Otherwise, there is no way to write pure components that don't use state, refs, or lifecycle methods.

Stateless functions are not treated internally as pure components, and are rerendered every time.

title: The jsx-a11y/no-static-element-interactions rule doesn't work properly in this preset
body:
Take this code (based on the [no-static-element-interactions example](https://github.com/evcohen/eslint-plugin-jsx-a11y/blob/master/docs/rules/no-static-element-interactions.md)): ```jsx import React from 'react'; const fn = () => {}; const element =
Save
``` The above code should pass the `jsx-a11y/no-static-element-interactions` rule, because the element has `role="button"`, so it's OK. And it _does_ pass that rule, when the rule is used on its own: ```yml rules: jsx-a11y/no-static-element-interactions: error ``` But when the rule is used as part of the airbnb present, it fails, no matter what you put in the `role` attribute: ```yml extends: - airbnb ``` ``` Visible, non-interactive elements should not have mouse or keyboard event listeners (jsx-a11y/no-static-element-interactions) ```

title: Fix error on function within 8.2
Add awareness for rules unsupported by ESLint
body:
I had no clue there were so many Airbnb JavaScript style rules that are currently not covered by ESLint. How do you feel about appending some note that mentions their existence to the ESLint configs?

I imagine this would help push more JavaScript to follow the full set of guides in multiple ways.
* The devoted could read them (and spread them directly).
* It could encourage the development of ESLint plugins for the uncovered guides. Many of them seem relatively easy to cover even!
* It could inspire people to help all get all guides across to people in ways I haven't thought of

title: Contradiction Between 23.2 (getters/setters) and 23.4 (get() and set() functions)
body:
There appears to be a direct contradiction between [23.2](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript#accessors--no-getters-setters) and [23.4](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript#accessors--consistent). 

The documentation provides reasoning that the use of getters and setters "... cause unexpected side effects and are harder to test, maintain, and reason about.". But then allows the use .of `get(key)` and `set(key, val)` which are actually much, much worse for unexpected side-effects, testability, maintainability and reasoning about and provide little benefit over accessors and have huge incompatibilities with the vast majority of smart IDEs.

**get() and set() functions Does not...**
1. Allow refactoring when property names change. You must find all usages of `jedi.get('lightsaber')` manually. This is incompatible with most smart IDEs and may lead to enormous application-wide failures if one is missed.
2. Allow you to define read-only properties without placing logic in the `set(key, val)` that throws for particular properties or requires using `Object.defineProperty` in the constructor to declare the backing variable as read-only. e.g. `Object.defineProperty('someProperty', {writable: false});`
3. Catch misspellings of keys e.g. `jedi.set('lightsabber', lightsaberInstance)`. IDEs will not show a warning or error at all.
4. Allow the developer to quickly glance at the class to determine it's "shape". It's not immediately clear which properties are available or whether they are read-only or writable.
5. Provide any auto-complete feedback whatsoever. Most developers don't use VIM or Notepad to write large scale enterprise software. No intelli-sense or autocomplete makes developing painful.
6. Provide a concrete way to access or set properties. When do I use `get()` over direct property access? When should I use `set()`? If set gives a developer trouble, she/he might just access the backing property directly.
7. Many more reasons this is a problem...

**getters/setters Does...**
1. Provide a concrete class shape that is easily knowable and readily identifiable read-only properties.
2. Provide an easy (and native) way to enforce read-only properties without implementing this logic manually and for every read-only property.
3. Provides feedback from the IDE including autocomplete and easy refactoring. Most IDEs will complain when a property name is misspelled when accessing it.
4. Allows the developer the flexibility to initialize the property value when first accessed (if needed) without having to create a huge switch statement in a `get(key)` function.
5. Allows the developer to cast primitives without having a huge switch statement in a `set(key, val)` function. e.g. `set variable(value){ value = +value; this.backingVariable = value;}`

**recommendation**
Allow getters/setters "with caution" and define an acceptable use case and provide implementation examples.

title: What is the benefit of prefer-default-export?
body:
The docs don't have a **Why** section for `prefer-default-export`, and I'm not seeing the benefit of it on my own. I would think that _not_ using default is _preferred_. With default exports, you lose refactoring power (if you rename the source `const`/`function`/`class`, it won't rename default imports).

As more of an edge case: it makes code less future-proof. i.e. if you create a file that will be a collection of errors, but it only starts with one error, to follow the linting rules, you'll have to have it `export default`, but then when you add the 2nd error at a later time, you'll have to do a bunch of refactoring that could have been prevented if the recommendation was to avoid default export.
